raw_text:
Franz Ferdinand's art school lesson
 
 Scottish rock band Franz Ferdinand, who shot to prominence in 2004, have won two Brit Awards.
 
 With their self-titled debut, Franz Ferdinand have achieved what most rock bands crave - high credibility and critical acclaim while also selling stacks of CDs. They have risen to the head of the UK's art rock ranks with an album of songs that are catchy, creative and original enough to sound fresh. With a cool, spiky, fun sound previously associated with bands like Talking Heads, they hit upon a style that had been out of fashion for a while and so was ripe for another airing. Their first UK single hit number three last January, followed by two more top 20 hits, while the album has sold more than 600,000 copies in 11 months on release. In September it was named album of the year winning the prestigious Mercury Music Prize.
 
 On the festivals circuit, they have been one of the main attractions for huge crowds at Glastonbury, T in the Park and Reading/Leeds. They have also found success in Japan, Europe and the US. By September the album had sold 500,000 in the States and total sales were pushing two million worldwide. They have been nominated for three Grammy awards in the US as well as the US music industry's Shortlist award, but lost the Shortlist prize to US band TV on the Radio. Nevertheless Franz Ferdinand were the only UK band to win an MTV Video Music Award this year, taking the breakthrough video crown for Take Me Out.
 
 The four-piece met two years ago when drummer Paul Thomson was working at the Glasgow art school where bassist Bob Hardy was studying. Singer Alex Kapranos was studying English at university but had friends at art school, and the line-up was completed when guitarist Nick McCarthy moved from Munich, Germany, to the city. At the turn of the year, Kapranos told BBC News Online the band were fed up with serious bands in "that post-rock thing that seemed to be doing its damndest to avoid any bloody tune".
 
 "We want people to go away from the gigs humming the tunes that we were singing. But at the same time bringing an edge to it." Franz Ferdinand had a question they asked themselves every time they wrote a song, Kapranos said. "Where's the fun in that?" they pondered at every stage, making enjoyment the top priority and ensuring they did not disappear up their own muso posteriors. The band started out with a DIY ethic that saw them take over a disused art-deco warehouse in Glasgow and rename it The Chateau. The venue soon became legendary - so well-known that the police spent a month trying to find it, eventually raiding it and arresting Kapranos. But the charges of running an illegal bar and contravening health and safety, fire hazard and noise abatement laws were dropped.
 
 The band took over an abandoned Victorian courtroom and jail instead, and named that The Chateau. The buzz about the band soon spread around the music industry and 40 record labels turned up to one gig in Glasgow - which the band thought was "totally ridiculous". "I'm really glad it was almost comical because we weren't overwhelmed by the seriousness of it," Kapranos said. They signed with independent label Domino, home of Smog, Sebadoh and Four Tet, in June 2003.
llama3.2:1b: Franz Ferdinand's debut album sold more than 600,000 copies in UK and over 2 million worldwide within two months.
The band won the Mercury Music Prize as their album was named Album of the Year.
They have performed at numerous festivals such as Glastonbury, T in the Park, Reading/Leeds, and appeared on MTV Video Music Awards.
The band's early success can be attributed to their DIY ethos and a focus on catchy songs with an edge, which led them to self-tape their album and record it in abandoned locations.
llama3.2:3b: Franz Ferdinand is a Scottish rock band that rose to prominence in 2004.
They won two Brit Awards and achieved critical acclaim for their debut album, which sold over 600,000 copies in the UK within 11 months.
The band has toured extensively, including Glastonbury and Reading/Leeds festivals, and found success in Japan, Europe, and the US.
They were nominated for three Grammy awards and won an MTV Video Music Award for their breakthrough video "Take Me Out."
gemma2:2b: Franz Ferdinand is a popular Scottish rock band that won two Brit Awards and topped UK art rock charts with their self-titled debut album.
The album was praised by critics and fans alike, achieved international success with over two million sales worldwide, and won the prestigious Mercury Music Prize.
The band members met in Glasgow while working or studying at art school and sought to bring a fun and catchy sound to music that had been too serious.
They started their own venue, The Chateau, which became a legendary spot known for its unique atmosphere.
Franz Ferdinand signed with Domino Records and achieved widespread recognition within the music industry.
qwen2.5:0.5b: French singer-songwriter Franz Ferdinand achieved two Brit Awards, became a hit in the UK rock scene, and has been nominated for an MTV Video Music Award this year.

They were formed by Paul Thomson at Glasgow Art School where Bob Hardy studied music and later moved to the city with guitarist Nick McCarthy, building their self-titled debut album of songs that are catchy, creative and original enough to sound fresh.
The band's first UK single hit number three in January and sold more than 600,000 copies in just one month.
In September they won a Mercury Music Prize.
They have performed at Glastonbury, Reading/Leeds, T in the Park and Japan, Europe and the US.
At festivals like the Guardian Dome (Glastonbury), The Tate Modern (London), and Reading Festival, they've been successful with over 2 million worldwide sales.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Scottish rock band Franz Ferdinand, known for their self-titled debut album, achieved significant success after 2004 with two Brit Awards nominations, including the Mercury Music Prize win for their album of "catchy, creative, original" songs that revived post-rock styles from the past and sold over 600,000 copies in the UK.
They were nominated for three Grammy awards but lost to US band TV on the Radio.
Franz Ferdinand gained popularity at festivals like Glastonbury, T in the Park, Reading/Leeds, and Japan, Europe, and the United States.
Their album reached number one in 13 countries and sold over 2 million copies worldwide by September, including 500,000 units in the US.
qwen2.5:3b: Scottish rock band Franz Ferdinand rose to prominence in 2004 winning two Brit Awards for their self-titled debut album.
The album was catchy, original and critical success; topping charts, earning the prestigious Mercury Music Prize, and selling over 600,000 copies worldwide.
They've performed at major festivals and gained popularity in Japan, Europe, and US.
Their unique sound influenced by bands like Talking Heads appealed to audiences who sought something different from post-rock styles.
Franz Ferdinand's music features catchy tunes that listeners can hum along with; enjoyment is their top priority.
They started out DIY, taking over an art-deco warehouse as The Chateau, which eventually led to signing with independent label Domino in 2003.
opencoder:1.5b: Franz Ferdinand's art school lesson, released on August 15, 2021, is a tribute to the rock band who met in 2004.
With their debut album, they achieved high credibility and critical acclaim while also selling stacks of CDs.
They have risen to the top of UK's art rock ranks with an album that combines elements of fun, creativity, and critical acclaim.
The album has sold over 600,000 copies worldwide within 11 months on release.
It has won the prestigious Mercury Music Prize and has been nominated for three Grammy awards in the US.
smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and to the point, preserving key ideas and details from the original text.

	* With their self-titled debut, Franz Ferdinand have achieved what most rock bands crave - high credibility and critical acclaim while also selling stacks of CDs.

Their success in UK music industry
	* They have been nominated for three Grammy Awards in the US as well as the US music industry's Shortlist award, but lost the Shortlist prize to TV on the Radio.

The four-piece band
	* At the turn of the year, Franz Ferdinand told BBC News Online that they were fed up with serious bands in "that post-rock thing that seemed to be doing its damndest to avoid any bloody tune".

Their question and approach to writing songs
	* Where's the fun in that?
- where is the fun in writing a song, according to Franz Ferdinand.
They approached writing songs as an experiment, making enjoyment their top priority and ensuring they did not abandon this approach.

The band's DIY ethos
	* They started out with a DIY ethic that saw them take over a disused art-deco warehouse and rename it The Chateau.
The venue soon became legendary - so well-known that the police spent a month trying to find it, eventually raiding it and arresting Kapranos.

Their gig at 40 record labels
	* The band took over an abandoned Victorian courtroom and jail instead, and named that The Chateau.

Their signing with independent label Domino
	* They signed with independent label Domino, home of Smog, Sebadoh and Four Tet, in June 2003.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Franz Ferdinand, a Scottish rock band known for achieving high credibility with critical acclaim while selling stacks of CDs, won two Brit Awards.
Their debut album was catchy, creative, and original, setting new standards in the UK's art rock ranks.
The band's unique style emerged from an abandoned art-deco warehouse, blending DIY elements into their performance.
Known for a fun, edge-of-mushroom approach to music, Franz Ferdinand performed at festivals like Glastonbury and sold over 600,000 copies in its first month on release.
They were nominated for Grammy awards, including the Breakthrough Video Award, and won the MTV Video Music Award.
The band's story includes a humorous take on post-rock trends.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Scottish rock band Franz Ferdinand, known for their catchy, creative, and original sound, have won two Brit Awards in the past year.
With an album that has sold over 600,000 copies in just a few months on release, they've emerged as one of the main attractions on the festival circuit.

The band was also nominated for three Grammy awards in the US this year, and their success continues to gain them popularity among international audiences, with the latest album receiving critical acclaim and charting at number three in the UK charts.
Despite a nomination for a Shortlist award in the US, they have been nominated only in two categories for the MTV Video Music Awards.

In this article, the summary of the band's success is highlighted, including their rise to prominence through self-titled debut album that has gained them popularity among international audiences and received critical acclaim.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Franz Ferdinand are a Scottish rock band from Glasgow that have achieved worldwide fame with their debut album, which sold over six million copies in the US alone.
Their music is catchy, creative, and original enough to sound fresh.
With their self-titled debut, Franz Ferdinand managed to win two prestigious awards at the Mercury Music Prize and the Shortlist award.

They also performed at major festivals such as Glastonbury, T in the Park, and Reading/Leeds, where they sold over two million copies of their album in the US and reached number three on the UK charts.
Franz Ferdinand's music has been supported by high-profile collaborations, including with Talking Heads, who they won a Grammy award for their collaboration on their debut album.
phi:2.7b: Franz Ferdinand is a British rock band that gained fame for their unique art-rock sound in 2004.
The band, consisting of four members, won two Brit Awards, and has sold millions of copies of their debut album.
They have also been nominated for three Grammy awards.
The band met while one member was working at an art school, and started out with a DIY approach to their music.
Despite their success, they remain true to their roots by focusing on making enjoyment the top priority in their songwriting process.
orca-mini:3b: Scottish rock band Franz Ferdinand has won two Brit Awards and achieved what most rock bands strive for - high credibility and critical acclaim while also selling stacks of CDs.
They have risen to the head of the UK's art rock ranks with an album of songs that are catchy, creative, and original enough to sound fresh.

Their self-titled debut album has sold more than 600,000 copies in 11 months on release and they have been nominated for three Grammy awards in the US as well as the US music industry's Shortlist award.
In September, their album Take Me Out won the breakthrough video crown at the MTV Video Music Awards.
The band formed two years ago when drummer Paul Thomson was working at the Glasgow art school where bassist Bob Hardy was studying.
Guitarist Nick McCarthy moved from Munich, Germany, to the city and singer Alex Kapranos was studying English at university.
They met at the art school and became friends.
The four-piece named their band after a character in a play by Serbian author August Strindberg.
hermes3:3b: Franz Ferdinand, Scottish art rock band, won acclaim for catchy, creative debut album.
Band members met at Glasgow art school, forming four-piece in 2002.
The Chateau became their DIY venue; later signed by Domino Records.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Scottish rock band Franz Ferdinand gained popularity in 2004 with their self-titled debut album, achieving high credibility, critical acclaim, and substantial sales.
The album's catchy, creative, and original songs helped the band rise to the top of UK's art rock ranks.
They performed at major festivals such as Glastonbury, T in the Park, and Reading/Leeds, and had success in Japan, Europe, and the US.
The band members met at an art school in Glasgow, and their approach to music prioritized fun and enjoyment while singing original songs.
Initially operating with a DIY ethic, Franz Ferdinand eventually signed with independent label Domino.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Scottish rock band Franz Ferdinand rose to fame in 2004, winning two Brit Awards and achieving both critical acclaim and commercial success with their self-titled debut album.
Their catchy, creative sound, reminiscent of Talking Heads, helped them stand out, leading to hit singles and over 600,000 album sales in the UK within 11 months.
The album won the Mercury Music Prize and gained international success, selling nearly two million copies worldwide, including 500,000 in the US.
They were nominated for three Grammy Awards and won an MTV Video Music Award for "Take Me Out."
The band formed in Glasgow, with members meeting through art school connections.
They embraced a fun, DIY approach, initially performing in a self-run venue, The Chateau, which was eventually shut down by police.
Their growing reputation attracted major industry attention, leading them to sign with independent label Domino in 2003.
stablelm2:1.6b: Scottish rock band Franz Ferdinand won multiple awards for their debut album, including album of the year at the Mercury Music Prize.
With catchy, creative songs, they gained popularity on both UK and international stages, selling over 2 million copies worldwide.
The band formed through mutual friends at an art school, with Alex Kapranos questioning the need for serious bands in a post-rock scene.
They maintained a DIY ethos while playing venues such as The Chateau, eventually signing with independent label Domino.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Franz Ferdinand, a Scottish rock band, gained prominence in 2004 and has since achieved significant success: two Brit Awards for their self-titled debut album, which features catchy, creative, and original songs with a distinctive style reminiscent of Talking Heads.
Their first UK single became a top 30 hit, and the album sold over 600,000 copies in 11 months.
In September, it won the Mercury Music Prize as album of the year.

The band's members met at Glasgow art school: singer Alex Kapranos was studying English, drummer Paul Thomson was working there, bassist Bob Hardy studied at the same institution, and guitarist Nick McCarthy relocated from Munich.
Inspired by a desire to create catchy tunes with an edge, they adopted a DIY approach, transforming disused spaces into iconic venues like The Chateau in Glasgow.
Despite initial interest from 40 record labels at one gig, Franz Ferdinand signed with independent Domino Records in June 2003.
Their success extended globally; they performed at major festivals in the UK and US, achieved top 20 singles, and sold over two million albums worldwide by September 2004.
They also received multiple Grammy nominations but lost to TV on the Radio for Shortlist awards.
Notably, Kapranos won an MTV Video Music Award for Breakthrough Video in 2005 for "Take Me Out."
